article.title: Corinth

template.arg: the modern Greek City of Corinth

article.paragraph: Corinth(IPAc-enˈkɔrɪnθ;Greek languageGreek: ,Krinthos,IPA-elˈkorinθospronEll-Korinthos.ogg) is a city and formermunicipalityinCorinthia,Peloponnese (region)Peloponnese,Greece. Since the 2011 local government reform it is part of the municipalityCorinth (municipality)Corinth, of which it is the seat and a municipal unit.Kallikratis lawGreece Ministry of Interiorel iconIt is the capital of Corinthia.

link.target: File:Pegasus - the symbol of New Corinth.jpg
link.part: Pegasus - the symbol of New Corinth.

article.paragraph: It was founded asNea KorinthosorNew Corinth( ) in 1858 after an earthquake destroyed the existing settlement of Corinth, which had developed in and around the site ofancient Corinth.
article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: Located aboutconvert78kmmi0west ofAthens, Corinth is surrounded by the coastal townlets of (clockwise)Lechaio,Isthmia (village)Isthmia,Kechries, and the inland townlets ofExamiliaand the archaeological site and village of ancient Corinth. Natural features around the city include the narrow coastal plain ofVocha (plain of)Vocha, theGulf of CorinthCorinthian Gulf, theIsthmus of Corinthcut by itsCorinth Canalcanal, the Saronic Gulf, theOneia Mountains, and the monolithic rock ofAcrocorinth, where the medievalacropoliswas built.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: FurtherAncient CorinthFile:Corinthian incised shard.svgthumbleftCorinthian incised shardCorinth derives its name fromAncient Corinth, acity-stateof antiquity. In 1858, the old city, now known as Archaia Korinthos ( ), locatedconvert3kmmionSW of the modern city, was totally destroyed by a magnitude 6.5 earthquake.Nea KorinthosorNew Corinthwas then built a few kilometers away on the coast of the Gulf of Corinth. A magnitude 6.3 earthquake in 1928 devastated the new city, which was then rebuilt on the same site.cite journalTsapanosTheodoros M.Deterministic seismic hazard analysis for the city of Corinth, central GreeceJournal of the Balkan Geophysical SocietyMarch 20111411-14http://www.balkangeophysoc.gr/online-journal/2011_V14/No1_March2011/JBGS_Vol_14_No1_March_2011_p00-14_Tsapanos_et_al.pdf21 July 2015etalIt was rebuilt again after a great fire in 1933.
article.heading: Demographics
article.paragraph: The Municipality of Corinth ( ) had a population of 58,192 according to the 2011 census, the second most populous municipality in thePeloponnese RegionafterKalamata.The municipal unit of Corinth had 38,132 inhabitants, of which Corinth itself had 30,176 inhabitants, placing it in third place behind Kalamata andTripoli, GreeceTripoliamong the cities of the Peloponnese Region.

The municipal unit of Corinth ( ) includes apart from Corinth proper the town ofArchaia Korinthos(2,198 inhabitants in 2011), the town ofExamilia(2,905 inhabitants), and the smaller settlements ofXylokeriza(1,316 inhabitants) andSolomos, CorinthiaSolomos(817 inhabitants).
article.heading: Economy
Industry
article.paragraph: Corinth is a major industrial hub at a national level.Corinth RefineryCorinth Refineriesis the largestoil refiningIndustrial complex inEurope. Copper cables, petroleum products, leather, medical equipment, marble, gypsum, ceramic tiles, salt, mineral water and beverages, meat products, and gums are produced nearby. As of 2005, a period ofdeindustrializationhas commenced as a large pipework complex, a textile factory and a meat packing facility diminished their operations.
article.heading: Transport

link.part: The rail road bridge over the Isthmus of Corinth.

article.heading: Roads
article.paragraph: Corinth is a major road hub. TheMoreas MotorwayA7toll roadtollmotorway for Tripoli and Kalamata, (and Sparta viaMoreas MotorwayA71toll roadtoll), branches off theMotorway 8 (Greece)A8/European route E94toll roadtollmotorway from Athens at Corinth. Corinth is the main entry point to the Peloponnesian peninsula, the southernmost area of continental Greece.
article.heading: Railways
article.paragraph: The city has been connected to theProastiakos, the Athens suburban rail network, since 2005, when the newCorinth railway stationwas completed.
article.heading: Port
article.paragraph: The port of Corinth, located north of the city centre and close to the northwest entrance of theCorinth Canal, at 37 56.0 N / 22 56.0 E, serves the local needs of industry and agriculture. It is mainly a cargo exporting facility.

It is an artificial harbour (depth approximatelyconvert9mft, protected by a concretemole (architecture)mole(length approximately 930 metres, width 100 metres, mole surface 93,000 m2). A new pier finished in the late 1980s doubled the capacity of the port. The reinforced mole protects anchored vessels from strong northern winds.

Within the port operates acustomsoffice facility and aHellenic Coast Guardpost. Sea traffic is limited to trade in the export of local produce, mainly citrus fruits, grapes, marble, aggregates and some domestic imports. The port operates as a contingency facility for general cargo ships,bulk carriersandROROs, in case ofstrike actionstrikesatPiraeusport. There is aferryline (RORO) connecting Corinth toItaly.
article.heading: Ferries
Canal

link.target: File:Corinth Canal in an old postcard.jpg
link.part: The Corinth Canal in an old postcard.

link.target: File:Corinth Canal by Frank van Mierlo.jpg
File:Istmo de Corinto ESC large ISS011 ISS011-E-13188.JPG
link.part: Aerial photograph of theIsthmus of Corinth.

article.paragraph: TheCorinth Canal, carrying ship traffic between the westernMediterranean Seaand theAegean Sea, is aboutconvert4kmeast of the city, cutting through theIsthmus of Corinththat connects the Peloponnesian peninsula to the Greek mainland, thus effectively making the former an island. The builders dug the canal through the Isthmus at sea level; no locks are employed. It isconvert6.4kmin length and onlyconvert21.3mwide at its base, making it impassable for most modern ships. It now has little economic importance.

The canal was mooted in classical times and an abortive effort was made to build it in the 1st century AD. Construction finally got underway in 1881 but was hampered by geological and financial problems that bankrupted the original builders. It was completed in 1893, but due to the canal's narrowness, navigational problems and periodic closures to repair landslips from its steep walls, it failed to attract the level of traffic anticipated by its operators. It is now used mainly for tourist traffic.
article.heading: Sport
article.paragraph: The city'sassociation footballteam isKorinthos F.C.(..E.), established in 1999 after the merger of Pankorinthian Football Club () and Corinth Football Club (). During the 2006-2007 season, the team played in the Greek Fourth Division's Regional Group 7. The team went undefeated that season and it earned the top spot.waybackhttp://www.paskorinthos.gr/2006-2007.html20100723000059This granted the team a promotion to theGamma EthnikiGamma Ethnik (Third Division)for the 2007-2008 season. For the 2008-2009 season, Korinthos F.C. competed in the Gamma Ethniki (Third Division) southern grouping.

article.heading: Other locations named after Corinth

template.arg: List of locations named after Corinth, Greece

article.paragraph: Due to its ancient history and the presence ofPaul the ApostleSt. Paul the Apostlein Corinth some locations all over the world have been named Corinth.
